newsitem.title: UK: UK wool textile industry welcomes GATT exemption.
newsitem.headline: UK wool textile industry welcomes GATT exemption.

text.p: The chairman of the top UK wool textile body welcomed the European Commission's decision to exclude woven wool textiles from trade liberalisation in 1998, but said tops should have been included too.

"We are very pleased that the Council of Ministers has accepted the arguments of the UK and other governments and removed wool cloths from phase two of the Multifibre Arrangement," John Lambert of the Confederation of British Wool Textiles (CBWT) told Reuters on Friday.
The Multifibre Arrangement governs world textile trade quotas and is being dismantled in three phases ending in 2005 under the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs (GATT).
The European Commission agreed to amend the list of textiles to be re-integrated into GATT in 1998 at a meeting earlier this week, removing woven woollen textiles.
But Lambert said the textile industry was disappointed that woollen tops had not been exempted too.
"The position of the UK government and the CBWT is that tops should remain protected unless Argentina and Brazil reciprocate and open their markets up to UK exporters," he said.
"An as industry we are still very concerned about the trade barriers we face in a large number of markets, particularly in South America, South East Asia and in India," he added.

Elizabeth Peacock MP, chairman of the All Party Parliamentary Wool Textile lobby group, which helped to put the CBWT's case to the Department of Trade and Industry, described the Commission's verdict on cloths as "a very satisfactory outcome".
